SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. He reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for approximately five weeks. He has been adhering to his medications but has struggled with his diet due to recent home renovations. He denies fever, chills, and diarrhea but endorses shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour. He also reports a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Positive slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Fluid retention, evidenced by physical examination and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and stumbled, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is present. No calf pain is reported.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes, resolved on Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening and pain management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent diet has not been ideal, and his hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side, and in-office blood pressure is elevated.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee pain well and does not require further workup at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He is managing his depression well with medication.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. His blood pressure in the office today is 120/80 mmHg.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He denies any significant shortness of breath, except for occasional difficulty during humid weather and pollen season.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Denies significant shortness of breath. Mild shortness of breath with exertion.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle aches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing well with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to continue current management strategies.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is controlled in the office today.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Status post lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well, exercising regularly, and has no significant respiratory issues.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Long-standing iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for evaluation of long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient reports being anemic since the age of 13. She was recently unable to donate blood due to anemia. The patient experiences fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also reports worsening anxiety and depression.

The patient had a hysterectomy in 1996 and a colonoscopy approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. She denies having a pacemaker, defibrillator, sleep apnea, or using oxygen at night. She consumes alcohol occasionally (once or twice a year) and takes ferrous sulfate (25 mg tablets, twice daily) and over-the-counter vitamin B12 supplements.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy (1996).

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: occasional (once or twice a year).

FAMILY HISTORY

Not provided.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate (25 mg tablets, twice daily).
Vitamin B12 (over-the-counter).

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Normal physical exam without significant findings.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule the patient for these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

2. Hematologist referral: Send a referral to Dr. Flores, a hematologist, for further evaluation and management of anemia.

3. Iron supplementation: Instruct the patient to continue taking ferrous sulfate with orange juice (for vitamin C) for the next 8-12 weeks, then reassess blood work (CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate).

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male, presenting for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient has been experiencing worsening headaches over the past few months, with no prior history of headaches. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient's past clinical history is unremarkable.

The patient describes the headaches as a dull nagging ache located behind his eyes, with a severity of 6 out of 10. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago. The headaches tend to be worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms such as fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has recently noticed bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer
Marital status: Married for 25 years
Alcohol, smoking, and recreational drug use: None

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None

RESULTS

MRI brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm, normal ventricles, no other abnormalities noted.
Labs (3/3/21): CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, all other results normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma

PLAN

1. Refer the patient for a full eye exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery to assess for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in the past.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for a new patient evaluation due to a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports having chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. She has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since then. The patient had a normal cardiac workup in the ER, and they suspected a GI-related issue.

The patient reports that the chest pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and felt like a sharp pain. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during the episode. The pain was worse with eating. She has no current issues with abdominal pain or bowel movements.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal.

Surgical
Cholecystectomy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None provided.

ALLERGIES

None provided.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, weight gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, blood in the stools.
Positive for past chest pain and difficulty swallowing, which resolved after four days.

PHYSICAL EXAM

The patient has mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. The rest of the exam is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Possible etiologies for the patient's past symptoms include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. It is suspected that the patient had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. The patient should follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney evaluation for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, weighing 4 pounds 8 ounces. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues associated with her syndrome, and the patient is here for a kidney evaluation.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Feeding difficulties.
Reflux.
Developmental delays.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If the ultrasound results are normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed. If abnormal, determine next steps and future follow-up at the Town Center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow up as needed based on the findings. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has tried icing, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not recorded.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Upper extremities: Normal range of movement in left arm. Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture with evidence of extra-articular fracture proximal to the radial ulnar joint and dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. Ulnar styloid fracture is present.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a right wrist Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace and pain management using 50 mg of Ultram every six hours. The patient will undergo surgery to correct the fracture, followed by a six-week bracing period. Physical therapy will be initiated a few weeks after surgery, with an assessment to determine the frequency of sessions. The patient will return for a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to schedule surgery as soon as possible and to follow post-operative care instructions, including bracing and physical therapy. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office for further evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: not provided
Respiration: not provided
No fever.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, belly pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, swelling, and discomfort with flexion and extension.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, previously known.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support. Advise icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily. Encourage elevation and rest.
- Follow-up: Reevaluate in a few weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the importance of diet and sodium reduction.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary guidance.
- Follow-up: Monitor blood pressure and reevaluate the need for medication adjustments.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in a few weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it may be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the shoulder. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. The pain is described as internal and involving the whole kneecap. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for pain, as the episodes are brief and infrequent. The patient is concerned about an upcoming trip that will involve walking and line dancing, and she is hesitant to participate due to her knee issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies any other joint pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medication regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage. Encourage the patient to continue taking metformin as prescribed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports having good family support and has been receiving assistance from the nursing staff and office.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Reports a sore throat and decreased appetite, but no difficulty swallowing.
Psychiatric: Patient reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong with good support systems in place.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy noted.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs appreciated.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles noted bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema noted.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation treatment.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current regimen of cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy and 45 Gy of radiation. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical intervention.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and bilateral crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat is likely due to inflammation in the esophagus from radiation.
- Medical Treatment: In addition to prednisone, prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent international travel to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has been recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness or diarrhea.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab results are consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other symptoms that would indicate a more severe immunodeficiency.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibodies and potential immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to monitor for any infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. He has been engaging in pottery activities recently, which may have contributed to the pain. The patient has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain with radiation into the forearm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and inconsistent compliance with medications.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during activity.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes with difficulty finding a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them before. His primary care doctor ordered a CT scan, which showed a kidney stone, and referred him to a urologist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Patient may continue to take Tylenol for additional pain relief.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient describes the ulcer as having a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with 2-3 days remaining in the course. He has experienced some chills and a fever of 99.7°F. The patient also reports calf muscle cramping and a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle. He has had difficulty catching his breath and has been coughing more frequently in the last two days.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range and one spike at 500-600. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7. He has been using diabetic shoes and inserts and has been compliant with checking his feet daily.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail with his wife.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Respiratory: Reports difficulty catching breath and increased coughing.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell and drainage.
Musculoskeletal: Reports calf muscle cramping and red streak along the inside of the calf muscle.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Skin: 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Pain: Patient reports no pain when the affected area of the wound is pressed.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the following plan with the patient:

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on the results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf and leg closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Recommend the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist for diabetes management and to maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with associated pain and erythema.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning pain and annoyance.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and typical arthritic pain.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension
- Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes
- Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order Hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Patient inquired about kidney function; order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
